### Introduction

When consulting a dictionary for the definition of "word," we find the following description
• "a single unit of language that has meaning and can be spoken or written:..."
While this definition is precise, there remains an aspect worthy of further examination - one that is directly connected to the summation rules discussed in another text

text.text:
Reflection 1: Meaning Through Time

Can a word's meaning change over time? Would it be possible to measure such changes?

### Dictionary

When we have doubts about the meaning of a word, it is recommended to consult a dictionary to understand it according to established linguistic norms.

However, people have the freedom to create new words or modify the meanings of existing ones in their daily lives. This phenomenon was explored by Elena Herraiz in one of her videos, where she addresses the question: *Is orthography classist?*

These changes, integrated into our daily lives, can also be observed in orthographic references. For example, the *Dictionary of the Portuguese Language* currently notes that the verb "filhar" is no longer in use, though it was frequently employed in medieval texts

source.text: HERCULANO, Alexandre, PMH, Scriptores, Volumen I…, p. 165

text.text:
Reflection 2: Changes

In this section, we observed that even within a "short" period—less than a millennium—words can fall into disuse. Could a longer timeframe further amplify shifts in meaning?

### Changes in Time Perception

#### The Challenges

When we look back in time, we face challenges in understanding historical texts and discerning how people perceived nature in those eras. In addition to the lack of contemporary dictionaries, we often encounter incomplete records on various subjects. This leads us to infer past beliefs and thoughts based on fragmented sources

Reflection 3: Contradictions

The deeper we delve into research, the more we realize how much knowledge remains undiscovered—and how many questions still need to be asked to uncover new answers.

Given that ancient knowledge was more limited than our current understanding, were ancient texts closer to or further from our modern comprehension of nature?

#### Day is day, thus...

Sometimes, concepts that seem obvious today—because they are part of our daily lives—can lead us to assume they have always been understood the same way. However, examining the past reveals that what is obvious now was not necessarily so in other eras. A key example is the measurement of time.

When analyzing ancient Sumerian texts, such as the Sumerian King List, we encounter something extraordinary: the earliest kings are described as having reigns lasting thousands of years, with one even reaching 43,200 years

source.text: History Tracers Team, Sumérios: Os reiyes mitológicos

text.text:
Given the biological implausibility of millennial lifespans, it is possible that the Sumerians also had a different understanding of shorter time periods, such as a "day."

Consulting modern dictionaries, we find multiple definitions of "day"

• "A1. a period of 24 hours, especially from twelve o'clock one night to twelve o'clock the next night."
  • "a period of 24 hours, esp. from 12 o’clock one night to 12 o’clock the next night, or the part of this period after the sun rises but before it goes down, when there is light"
Beyond dictionaries, encyclopedic sources clarify further

• "day, time required for a celestial body to turn once on its axis; especially the period of the Earth’s rotation. The sidereal day is the time required for the Earth to rotate once relative to the background of the stars—i.e., the time between two observed passages of a star over the same meridian of longitude... The solar day is the fundamental unit of time in both astronomical practice and civil life. It begins at midnight and runs through 24 hours, until the next midnight. A day is commonly divided into two sets of 12 hours for ordinary timekeeping purposes;..."

Since we have no Sumerian dictionaries or encyclopedias, we must rely on original texts to understand their perception of time. H. Radau’s studies on Sumerian cosmology suggest that their concept of day and night was tied to the Sun’s movement, including the idea of a "world-edifice"—a cosmic structure. Later, Samuel Noah Kramer analyzed Sumerian tablets (including one in the Pushkin Museum) and found that they believed the Sun traveled through the "Nether World" after sunset
These findings indicate that the Sumerians lacked knowledge of celestial mechanics, leading to

Reflection 4: On Time

If the Sumerians did not understand Earth’s rotation or its orbit around the Sun, could this limitation explain their exaggerated chronologies?
Herodotus confirms this conception of time, noting that the Greeks adopted the Babylonian 12-hour division—later split into two 12-hour periods for day and night
This geocentric view was not unique to Mesopotamia. As Aguilar-Moreno explains regarding Mesoamerican cultures

• "...Ball courts symbolized the universe, and the ball game itself was a metaphor for celestial movements—particularly those of the Sun, Moon, and Venus. The ball’s motion represented the Sun’s journey into and out of the underworld, with the court’s narrow alley symbolizing the entrance...."

exercise_v2.question: Palavras podem ser criadas ou excluídas do vocabulário no tempo?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: A língua está viva, e comparando dicionários de tempos distintos, podemos ver que mudanças estão sempre ocorrendo.

exercise_v2.question: Dia e noite possuem relação com a rotação da terra ao redor do sol. Este sempre foi o entendimento de toda a humanidade?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Textos antigos, e tradições religiosas, mostram que nosso entendimento sobre dia, noite, e o universo como um todo, é algo bem recente. Desta forma, ao tratarmos medidas de tempo em um passado distante, como as conhecemos hoje, estamos cometendo um equívoco, que é conhecido como anacronismo.
